bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to R.A. Amador, April 25, 1925

div1.p: Kean approves of Amador's idea for a popular history of yellow fever. He relates his recollections of the X.Y. yellow fever case.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to R.A. Amador, April 25, 1925
div1.opener:
FROM GEN. J. R. KEAN
April 23, 1925.
Dr. R. A. Amador,
Legacion de Panama,
Paris, France.
My dear Dr. Amador:
div1.p:
It was indeed a great pleasure to get your letter
of the 5th and I felt like I had met again an old friend.

I think it is an admirable idea for you to write
a pamphlet to let the people at Panama know that in the
yellow fever work Reed was the leader whom all followed and
his an original work. As Gorgas himself wrote to Reed in
August, 1901, his credit was only that of the man who first
applied Reed's discoveries on a large scale.

Yes, I know the story of “X.Y.” I looked him up
a number of years ago when I was in the Surgeon General's
Office and found out his name and diagnosis. I am sorry to
say I have forgotten the name but I remember perfectly well
the other facts. Your memory has played you a trick in think-
ing that he had a brokenffemur. The trouble was much less
serious, namely gonorrhea. When Lazear went into the ward
with his mosquitoes and asked who would be willing to feed
them, this cavalryman “X.Y.” volunteered. The man was about
ready for duty and was returned to duty the next day by the
Ward Surgeon who did not know of this incident. He came back
the next week with fever which you correctly diagnosed yellow
fever. When Reed came back from the United States where he
was at this time, he went to see this man and tried to get
him to admit that while he was on duty he had broken the
quarantine and gone to Quemados. Reed even offered him a
twenty-dollar gold piece if he would admit it but the cavalry-
man said “I would like to have your twenty-dollar gold piece
but I do not see how it would help you for me to tell a lie,
and I did not leave the camp”.

The book written by Prof. Howard Kelly is called
“Walter Reed and Yellow Fever”. He got out a new edition
last year.

It is a great pleasure to hear from you and I
hope that if you come to Washington you will be sure to
look me up. When you write your pamphlet, I hope you
will not fail to send me a copy.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, J. R. KEAN
Colonel, U.S. Army, Retired,
Editor. JRK/W
